quotes.author: Muḥammad Nāṣir ʾl-Dīn al-Albānī
quotes.body:
This is the best evidence for the recommendation to bath on the two ʿĪd celebrations, narrated by al-Bayhaqī:
A man once asked ʿAlī – Allah be pleased with him – about taking a full bath (ġusl).
He replied, “Wash every day if you want.”
The man said, “No, what I mean is al-ġusl.”
ʿAli replied, “al-Jumuʿah (Friday), the Day of ʿArafah, the Day of al-Naḥr (sacrificial slaughter, ʿĪd al-Adhā) and the Day of al-Fiṭr (the ʿĪd following Ramaḍān).”
The chain of narration is authentic.
quotes.title: Irwāʾ al-Ġalīl fī Takhrīj Aḥādīth Manār al-Sabīl

quotes.author: Muḥammad Nāṣir ʾl-Dīn al-Albānī
quotes.body:
From Abū Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: “There were two men from Baliyy, from the (tribe of) Qudā‘ah who accepted Islām and joined Allah‘s Messenger ﷺ.
Then one of them was martyred and the other one died a year later.
So Ṭalhah b. ʿUbaydillāh (may Allah be pleased with him) said: I saw the one delayed (in a dream) and he was entered into Paradise before the martyr, so I was surprised at that. So I mentioned that to Allah’s Messenger ﷺ.
So Allah’s Messenger ﷺ said: “Did he not fast Ramaḍān after him, and pray six-thousand (more) rakʿahs, and such and such Sunnah prayers?”
Reported by Aḥmad with a Ḥasan chain of narration.
[Ḥasan Ṣaḥīḥ]
quotes.title: Ṣaḥīḥ al-Tarġīb wa ʿl-Tarhīb

quotes.author: Ṣāliḥ al-Fawzān
quotes.body:
O Muslims! A great month is at hand, and a noble guest will visit you soon: {The month of Ramaḍān in which was revealed the Qurʿān, a guidance for mankind and clear proofs for the guidance and the criterion (between right and wrong)} [Al-Baqarah 2:185]
Allāh has ordained it‘s fast as one of the pillars of Islām, and standing during it’s night (for prayer) from the tremendous voluntary acts.
quotes.title: salihalfawzan

quotes.author: Muḥammad b. Ṣāliḥ al-ʿUthaymīn
quotes.body:
Question: Noble Shaykh, whoever prays the Tarāwīḥ (prayer) must he then continue to pray them all throughout Ramaḍān?
Answer: No he does not have to continue (to pray them) because it is a recommended (Sunnah) prayer in that if he prays them then he is rewarded and if he leaves them then he is not a sinner. However, (in leaving them) he misses out on a lot of good as we have said (before).
quotes.title: Fiqh al-ʿIbādāt

quotes.author: al-Shawkānī
quotes.body: Fasting the month of Ramaḍān is obligatory upon the sighting of the crescent by a trustworthy individual, or (in the case of the crescent not being sighted) by the month of Shaʿbān being completed. It is obligatory to fast for thirty days so long as the crescent of Shawwāl is not sighted before thirty days of Ramaḍān being completed. If the people of a particular land see and confirm the sighting of the crescent, it is upon the other countries to conform to this sighting. It is upon the fasting person to make the intention to fast before Fajr.
quotes.title: al-Fatḥ al-Rabbānī

quotes.author: Ibn al-Qūdāmah al-Maqdisī
quotes.body:
Laylah al-Qadr is sought during the last ten nights of Ramaḍān,
with the odd nights being more likely,
and the night of the twenty-seventh holding the greatest hope.
One should make the supplication narrated from ʿĀ'ishah, may Allah be pleased with her, who said, “O Messenger of Allah, if I find Laylah al-Qadr, what should I supplicate?”
He said: Say: “O Allah, You are Forgiving and love forgiveness, so forgive me.”
quotes.title: al-Muqniʿ fī Fiqh ʿl-Imām Aḥmad

quotes.author: al-Nasāʾī
quotes.body: Ibn ʿUmar (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ enjoined zakāt al-fīṭr upon the people at the end of Ramaḍān, a ṣāʿ of dates or a ṣāʿ of barley, upon everyone, free or slave, male or female, among the Muslims.
quotes.title: al-Sunan al-Kubrá

quotes.author: Ibn Taymiyyah
quotes.body:
Ibn ʿAbbās (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Messenger ﷺ said:
Jibrīl led me in Salāh twice at the House.
So he prayed al-Dhuhr the first day when the shadow was similar to the length of the strap of a sandal (just after midday).
Then he prayed al-ʿAṣr when an object was similar to the length of its shadow.
Then he prayed al-Maġrib when the sun had set and the fasting person breaks the fast.
Then he prayed al-ʿIshāʾ when the twilight had vanished.
Then he prayed al-Fajr when the true dawn began (before sunrise), and when eating is prohibited for the fasting person.
The second occasion he prayed al-Dhuhr when the shadow of everything was similar to the length of it, which was the time of al-ʿAṣr the day before.
He prayed al-ʿAṣr when the shadow of an object was about twice as long as it.
Then he prayed al-Maġrib at the same time as he did the first time.
Then he prayed al-ʿIshāʾ, the later one, when a third of the night had gone.
Then he prayed al-Fajr when the land glowed (before sunrise).
Then Jibrīl turned towards me and said: “O Muḥammad! These are the times of the Prophets before you,
and the time is what is between these two times (for each prayer).”
quotes.title: Sharḥ al-ʿUmdah Kitāb al-Ṣalāh

quotes.author: Ibn al-Qayyim
quotes.body: This is why the Prophet ﷺ used to recite the two Sūrahs (al-Kāfīrūn and al-Ikhlāṣ) in the Sunnāh prayer of al-Fājr, wa ʿl-Maġrib wa ʿl-Wītr prayer, which commence and conclude one's actions [of the day and night], so that the day would begin with Tawḥīd and end with Tawḥīd.
quotes.title: Ijtimāʿ al-Juyūsh

quotes.author: Ibn Taymiyyah
quotes.body:
He (may Allah have mercy on him) was asked: “If a person missed the ʿAṣr (afternoon prayer), and when he arrived to the masjid he found maġrib (sunset prayer) has started, which prayer should he pray first?”
Answer (may Allah have mercy on him): All Praise is due to Allah, the Lord of all that exists. He should pray maġrib with the Imām (the one leading the prayer at the masjid), then pray al-ʿAṣr afterwards, as agreed upon by all leading scholars.
However, should he repeat the maġrib prayer (after having prayed it with the Imām)?
This has two scholarly opinions.
The first is that he repeats. This is the saying of Ibn ʿUmar, Mālik, Abū Ḥanīfah and Aḥmad in what is most well-known about this issue.
The second opinion is that he does not repeat. This is the saying of Ibn ʿAbbās, the Shāfiʿī maḏhab, and the second opinion of the maḏhab of Imām Aḥmad.
The second opinion is more correct, for Allah did not make it obligatory on the person to pray a ṣalāh twice if he has feared Allah as much as he can.
And Allah knows best.
quotes.title: Majmūʿ al-Fatāwá

quotes.author: Muḥammad Nāṣir ʾl-Dīn al-Albānī
quotes.body:
Exaltations/Supplications of the Morning and Evening
Questioner: “When is the time for making the morning and evening adhkār (exaltations/ supplications)?”
al-Shaykh: “The morning adhkār are said after Fajr and the evening adhkār are said after ʿAṣr.”
Questioner: “Okay, what is the proof for this O Shaykh? We heard in Afġānistān that you said the evening adhkār are said after Maġrib?”
al-Shaykh: “No, it is after ʿAṣr.”
Questioner: “Okay, what is the dalīl (proof) for this?”
al-Shaykh: “Because al-masāʾ (ie: evening) linguistically starts after ʿAṣr.”
quotes.title: Silsilah al-Hudá wa ʾl-Nūr

quotes.author: Isḥāq al-Kawsaj
quotes.body:
I asked (Imām Aḥmad): “When is the hour that is hoped for on Friday?”
He replied: Most of the ḥadīths indicate that it is after al-ʿAṣr.
Isḥāq said: “After al-ʿAṣr — I hardly have any doubt about it, and I also hope for the time after the sun has passed its zenith.”
quotes.title: Masāʾil al-Imām Aḥmad wa Isḥāq Ibn Rahāwiyah

quotes.author: Aḥmad Shākir
quotes.body: And (Imām) Aḥmad said: Most of the aḥādīth about al-sāʿah (ie: the hour) in which it is hoped for al-duʿāʾ (ie: supplications) to be answered: it is after ṣalāt al-ʿAṣr, and it is hoped (too) after the sun has passed its zawāl (ie: zenith).
quotes.title: Musnad Aḥmad

quotes.author: ʿAbd al-Muḥsin al-ʿAbbād
quotes.body:
Jābir b. ʿAbd Allah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet ﷺ said:
“Friday is divided into twelve hours.
Amongst them there is an hour,
In which a Muslim does not ask Allah the Mighty and Majestic for anything but He the Mighty and Majestic gives it to him.
So seek it in the last hour after al-ʿAṣr (ie: the afternoon prayer).”
quotes.title: Sharḥ Abī Dāwūd

quotes.author: Ibn ʿAbd al-Barr
quotes.body: Whenever Saʿīd (b. Jubayr) prayed al-ʿAṣr prayer, he would not conversate with anyone up until the sun had set (ie: he was busy with supplication).
quotes.title: al-Tamhīd limā fī ʾl-Muwaṭṭaʾ min al-Maʿānī wa ʾl-Asānīd

quotes.author: ʿAbd al-Razzāq al-Ṣanʿānī
quotes.body:
From Ibn Jurayj that ʿAṭāʾ said: “If the day of al-Jumuʿah (ie: Friday) and ʿĪd al-Fīṭr fall on the same day, then a person should combine both prayers (ie: the Jumuah and ʿĪd prayer) and offer two rakʿats only, when he offers the prayer of ʿĪd.
And then he will remain like that until the time of Asr begins”.
(Ibn Jurayj) then said: Then he narrated to me: On an occasion the day of al-Jumuʿah and ʿĪd fell on the same day at the time of Ibn ʿl-Zubayr.
Ibn al-Zubayr said: “Two ʿĪds have fallen on the same day.”
Then he combined both of them and declared it as one,
And he offered two rakʿats on the day of al-Jumuʿah of ʿĪd and then he did not offer any prayer until the prayer of al-ʿAṣr“.
(ʿAṭāʾ) said: “As far as al-fuqahāʾ (ie: the jurists) are concerned then they do not tend to agree with this and as far as a person who does not contemplate the fiqh of this matter, then he denies it”.
(ʿAṭāʾ) said, “I also denied this fatwá and offered al-Dhuhr on that day.”
(He continued): Until later on, the tradition had reached to me that: “If two ʿĪds fall on the same day then it will be offered only one time (out of two prayers).”
(Ibn Jurayj) said: And it has also been narrated from Muḥammad b. ʿAlī b. al-Ḥusayn: “If two ʿĪds fall on the same day then they will be combined as one prayer.”
quotes.title: al-Muṣannaf

quotes.author: ʿAbd al-ʿAdhīm al-Munḏirī
quotes.body:
Abū Zuhayrah ʿUmārah b. Ruwaybah (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Messenger ﷺ said: “One who offers prayer before the rising of the sun, and the setting of the sun will not enter the Fire.” This is referring to al-Fajr and al-ʿAṣr.
Reported by Muslim.
quotes.title: al-Tarġīb wa ʾl-Tarhīb

quotes.author: Muḥammad b. Ṣāliḥ al-ʿUthaymīn
quotes.body: Preserving the Fajr and ʿAṣr prayers is from the reasons for looking at the Face of Allah. Preserve the Fajr and ʿAṣr prayer, and you will look at the Face of Allah on the Day of Resurrection in the Gardens of Delight.
quotes.title: Sharḥ Riyaḍ al-Ṣāliḥīn

quotes.author: ʿAbd al-Muḥsin al-ʿAbbād
quotes.body:
Explanation of the ḥadīth: “Four before al-Dhuhr (noon prayer); there is no taslīm (concluding salutation) among them; for them the gates of heaven are opened.”
The compiler, may Allah have mercy on him, said: [ḥaddathanā Ibn al-Muthanná; ḥaddathanā Muḥammad b. Jaʿfar; ḥaddathanā Shuʿbah; he said: I heard ʿUbaydah narrating from Ibrāhīm, from Ibn Minjāb, from Qurthaʿ, from Abū Ayyūb (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet ﷺ who said: “Four before Dhuhr; there is no taslīm among them; for them the gates of heaven are opened.”
Abū Dāwūd said: It reached me from Yaḥyá b. Saʿīd al-Qaṭṭān that he said: If I were to narrate anything from ʿUbaydah, I would narrate this ḥadīth from him.
Abū Dāwūd said: ʿUbaydah is ḍaʿīf (weak).
Abū Dāwūd said: Ibn Minjāb is Sahm.
Abū Dāwūd — may Allah have mercy on him — brought the ḥadīth (prophetic report) of Abū Ayyūb (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet ﷺ said: “Four before Dhuhr; there is no taslīm among them; for them the gates of heaven are opened).”
This indicates the ṣalāh (prayer) of four before Dhuhr, and that there is no taslīm among them — its meaning is that they are connected, with no taslīm in the middle but rather at the end. However, the aḥādīth have come stating that the ṣalāh is two by two, and the ḥadīth contains this man about whom there is criticism.
al-Albānī graded this ḥadīth ḥasan (good), and I do not know what the basis of declaring it good is, for the man in the isnād (chain of transmission) is weak and underwent ikhtiṭlāṭ (confusion), and he is ʿUbaydah b. Muʿattib.
So if there are shawāhid (supporting narrations) or something relied upon other than this route, then there would be a case for it. And even if the ḥadīth were ṣaḥīḥ (authentic), what is preferable is that the rawātib (regular supererogatory prayers) and the nawāfil (supererogatory prayers) be performed two by two, and it is permissible to perform them as a continuous sequence if the ḥadīth from the Messenger of Allah ﷺ is authentic.
Shaykh Nāṣir — may Allah have mercy on him — authenticated the ḥadīth with the wording: “Four rakʿahs (units of prayer) after zawāl (when the sun passes the meridian) before Dhuhr; there is no taslīm between them; they are equivalent to the ṣalāt al-saḥar (pre-dawn prayer).”
It is in al-Silsilah al-Ṣaḥīḥah, volume three.
If the ḥadīth is authentic, then it is permissible to string them together, though not stringing them together is preferable.
Just as the night ṣalāh is “two by two,” it is permissible to combine as four on its own, and four on its own, and three on its own, as that has come from the Messenger of Allah—may Allah bless him and grant him peace—so connecting and separating are both permissible, but separating is preferable to connecting.
And if we say connecting them is allowed, then does one perform a middle tashahhud?
The answer that appears is that he does not perform it, so that it does not become as though it were Dhuhr; for if a person were to do that, it would be as though he had prayed Dhuhr.
quotes.title: Sharḥ Abī Dāwūd

quotes.author: Muḥammad Nāṣir ʾl-Dīn al-Albānī
quotes.body:
ʿUmar b. al-Khaṭṭāb (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Messenger (ﷺ) said: “Whoever sleeps without doing his regular ḏikr or part of it, then recites it during the time between the Fajr prayer and Dhuhr prayer, it will be recorded as if he had recited it at night.”
Reported by Muslim, Abū Dāwūd, al-Tirmiḏī, al-Nasāʾī, Ibn Mājah, and Ibn Khuzaymah in his Ṣaḥīḥ.
Ṣaḥīḥ
quotes.title: Ṣaḥīḥ al-Tarġīb wa ʿl-Tarhīb

quotes.author: al-Nasāʾī
quotes.body: Umm Ḥabībah (may Allah be pleased with her) that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: “Whoever prays four (rakʿahs) before al-Dhuhr and four after it, the Fire will not touch him.”
quotes.title: al-Sunan al-Kubrá

quotes.author: Rabīʿ b. Hādī al-Madkhalī
quotes.body:
Question: “What is the correct position for working according to the calendar times for the prayers and that which is printed and circulated among many of the people especially in the West? Is it simply according to the entrance of the time specified on the calendar or is it better to wait a little to be on the safe side? We would like from you noble Shaykh some instruction for those in charge on the Masjids. And if differing occurs amongst the people concerning this matter what do you advise them with?”
Answer: This requires precise experimenting and testing of these calendars by way of study from the Muslims ‘on the ground’ as they say.
They look at the time of Fajr on the calendar to see what hour and minute the calendar says, then they go outside of the city to a place that has no lights and they look for the light of Fajr in real time; as it has been described by the Messenger peace be upon him. If they see that it agrees with the calendar, they affirm it. If it differs then say to the Muslims, this differs from the actual time therefore wait this amount of time.
This problem is found in the Muslim countries now; in Morocco and other places; in Algeria and other places unfortunately. The Muslims have become careless with regards to their prayer. Some people have complained that they set the time for Fajr about fifteen minutes before it enters. And Allah knows best.
We said to the Salafis; ‘experiment’. Go outside of the cities and look at the time of Fajr in a place that is far from lights. Fajr will become clear to you upon its reality. If it agrees (with the calendar) all praises belong to Allah. We will be relieved from the suspicions, problems and delusions, and confusion of the people. If it does not agree (with the calendar) then we present this to the responsible authority at the ministry. We say to them, we have experimented, and we would like to go out with you all for a second experiment. We found this time while the calendar contradicts the real time. This is my view on issue.
quotes.title: rabee.net

quotes.author: Muḥammad b. Ṣāliḥ al-ʿUthaymīn
quotes.body:
A question for the esteemed Shaykh!
“I miss the Fajr prayer often,
and I do not pray (it) except after sunrise at the time I want to go to work.
And this matter might happen again and again, so is there any (sin) upon me?
And What should I do in order to stick to my prayer on time?”
Answer: Do a number of things.
Firstly: That you sleep early.
And it is for this reason the Prophet ﷺ used to hate (one's) sleeping before al-ʿIshāʾ and enganging in discussions after it.
So that a person may go to sleep early in order to wake up early.
Secondly: that you have an intention at the time of going to sleep. a resolve, and determination that you are going to wake up for Ṣalāt al-Fajr.
Then waking up will be easy for you.
Thirdly: is that you use an alarm clock you put by your head that sets off an alarm for you.
And if you are afraid that when it goes off, you will switch it off, turn off the sound, and keep sleeping, keep it away from you a bit.
And someone, out of concern for the prayer, would put the alarm clock in a tin can,
And keep it at a distance from himself, so that it would have a powerful sound, so he would wake up.
Do this.
There is nothing prohibiting (it).
If this were not easy for you, put a telephone by your head, if you have a telephone,
And tell one of your brothers: “When the Aḏān for al-Fajr is given, call me.”
What is important is that a person can do things which result in his waking up so that he can perform al-Fajr in its time.
And one who makes laziness a habit for himself will remain upon laziness.
As for prayer in other than its time, if one intended [that], then the prayer is not accepted.
It is rejected from him,
even if he were to pray it a thousand times,
due to the saying of the Prophet: “Whoever does an act that is not under our legislation, it will be rejected.”
meaning it is returned back to him (ie: not accepted).
quotes.title: al-Liqāʾ al-Shahrī

quotes.author: Aḥmad b. Ḥanbal
quotes.body: Abū Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that Allah's Messenger ﷺ said, “Our Lord, the Mighty and Majestic, comes every night down on the nearest Heaven to us when the last third of the night remains, saying: ”Is there anyone to invoke Me, so that I may respond to invocation? Is there anyone to ask Me, so that I may grant him his request? Is there anyone seeking My forgiveness, so that I may forgive him?"
quotes.title: al-Musnad

quotes.author: Ibn Rajab
quotes.body:
And some people who were known for this (to rely on the stars for knowledge of what may or may not happen) objected to the ḥadīth where the Prophet ﷺ said that Allah descends in the third of the night, so they said: “The third of the night differs depending on the country, and it is not possible that Allahs descension be at any specific time.” However, that which is obligatory to have knowledge of in Islām, is that this type of objection is completely disgusting.
And that if the Prophet Muḥammad ﷺ and His rightly guided Caliphates were to hear this from this person, they would not even look at him,
Rather they would take him to his punishment, and include him in al-mukhālifīn (ie: the group of those who go against the truth), al-munāfiqīn (ie: the hypocrites), and al-mukhaḏibīn (ie: the liars).
quotes.title: Bayān Faḍl ʿIlm al-Salaf ʿalá ʿIlm al-Khalaf

quotes.author: Muḥammad Nāṣir ʾl-Dīn al-Albānī
quotes.body:
When Does The Time of Ṣalāt al-ʿIshāʾ End?
Questioner: “Up until what time is it permissible to delay Ṣalāt al-ʿIshāʾ?”
The Shaykh: Up until half of the night (has passed),
Since that has been clearly stated in Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim,
From the ḥadīth of ʿAbd Allah b. ʿAmr b. al-ʿĀṣ (may Allah be pleased with him), who said: the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: “And the time for al-ʿIshāʾ is until half the night has passed.”
And (its time) is not until al-Fajr al-Ṣādiq (ie: the time of the true dawn prayer) appears,
For there is no dalīl (ie: proof) for that even if some of the Imāms say so,
Because that goes against this authentic ḥadīth, "And the time for al-ʿishāʾ is until half the night has passed.
Yes.
quotes.title: Silsilah al-Hudá wa ʾl-Nūr

quotes.author: Ibn Taymiyyah
quotes.body:
And in the wording of Abū Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger ﷺ said: The first deed for which a servant will be called to account on the Day of Resurrection is his ṣalāt (ie: prayer).
If it is complete, he will be successful and saved,
but if it is deficient or corrupted, he will have failed and lost.
So if there something is deficient in his obligatory prayers,
the Lord (the Mighty and Majestic) will say: “Look, are there any voluntary Prayers for my worshipper?”
So with the voluntary prayers what was deficient in his obligatory prayers will be completed.
Then the rest of his deeds will be treated in the same manner.
Reported by al-Tirmiḏī who said the ḥadīth is Ḥasan.
quotes.title: Majmūʿ al-Fatāwá

quotes.author: al-Bayhaqī
quotes.body:
Narrated Abū Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): When Allah's Messenger ﷺ made the (opening) takbīr for the prayer, he used to keep silent before his recitation (of the Qurʾān).
So we said (to the Prophet ﷺ): “May my parents be sacrificed for you!
We saw that you remain silent between al-takbīr wa ʿl-qirāʿah, what do you say (in the pause between takbīr and recitation)?”
(The Prophet ﷺ) said: I say: “Allahumma bāʿid baynī wa bayna khaṭāyāya kamā bāʿadta bayn al-mashriqi wa ʿl-maġribi (ie: O Allah, separate me from my sins as You have separated the East from the West),
Allahumma naqqinī min khaṭāyāya kamā yunaqqath-thawb ʿl-abyaḍu min ʿl-danasī (ie: O Allah, cleanse me of my transgressions as the white garment is cleansed of stains),
Allaahuma aġsilnī min khaṭāyāya, bith-thalji wa ʿl-māʿi wa ʿl-barad (ie: O Allah, wash away my sins with ice and water and frost).”
Reported by Muslim in his Ṣaḥīḥ from Zuhayr b. Ḥarb from Jarīr, and also by way of ʿAbd al-Wāḥid b. Ziyād b. ʿUmārah.
quotes.title: Shuʿab al-ʾĪmān

quotes.author: Muḥammad Nāṣir ʾl-Dīn al-Albānī
quotes.body:
The Messenger ﷺ used to order to being tranquil (in the rukūʿ);
and he said to the person who did not pray properly:
“Then raise your head until you are standing straight; [until every bone goes back to its place]”,
(and in a narration: “And when rise from rukūʿ; then straighten your back,
and raise your head until the bones go back to their joints.”)
And he mentioned to him: “That no one's prayer is complete, if he does not do that.”
quotes.title: Aṣl Ṣifah Ṣalāh al-Nabī ṢallAllāhu ʿAlayhi Wa Sallam

quotes.author: al-Bukhārī
quotes.body:
al-Bukhārī said: Whoever claims that raising the hands (in prayer) is a bidaʿh (ie: an innovation),
then he has defamed the Companions of the Prophet ﷺ,
and the Salaf and those who came after them,
and the people of al-Ḥijāz,
the people of al-Madīnah,
the people of Makkah,
and a number from the people of al-ʿIrāq
and the people of al-Shām,
the people of Yemen
and the scholars of Khurasān.
quotes.title: Rafʿ al-Yadayn fī ʿl-Ṣalāt

quotes.author: al-Ḏahabī
quotes.body:
Ibn al-Madīnī said to Abū ʿl-Walīd: “What excuse will you have before Allah, and by what will you argue when you stand before Him, for leaving the practice of raising the hands before and after bowing in prayer?”
So Abū ʿl-Walīd raised his hands after eighty years of not doing so.
quotes.title: Tārīkh al-Islām

quotes.author: Maʿmar b. Rāshid
quotes.body: ʿAbd al-Razzāq informed us, on the authority of Maʿmar, on the authority of Qatādah that Kaʿb (may Allah be pleased with him) said: “The first thing a woman will be asked about on the Day of Resurrection will be her ṣalāt (ie: prayer) and the ḥaqqi zawjihā (ie: rights of her husband).”
quotes.title: Jāmīʿ

quotes.author: Muḥammad b. Ṣāliḥ al-ʿUthaymīn
quotes.body:
The noble Shaykh was asked: “What is the ruling on placing the right hand on the left hand and placing it on the chest during prayer?
What is the ruling on placing both hands below the navel?
And is there any difference between men and women in this regard?”
He answered: Placing the right hand on the left hand in the prayer is Sunnah.
The evidence for this is the ḥadīth of Sahl b. Saʿd (may Allah be pleased with him): “The people were ordered to place their right hand on their left forearm in prayer.” Reported by al-Bukhārī.
But where the hands should be placed?
The answer: in this regard, the most correct opinion is that the hands should be placed on the chest.
Due to the ḥadīth of Wāʿil b. Ḥajar (may Allah be pleased with him): “The Prophet used to place his right hand on his left hand on his chest.”
Although the chain of narration of the ḥadīth is slightly weak, it is the most correct compared to other opinions.
Placing the hands on the heart on the left side is a bidaʿh (ie: innovation) that has no ʿaṣl (ie: basis).
As for placing the hands below the navel, there is an athar from ʿAlī to support this, but it is ḍaʿīf (ie: weak).
The ḥadīth of Wāʿil b. Ḥajar (of placing them on the chest) is stronger.
There is no difference between men and women in this ruling,
because the general principle is that men and women are equal in al-aḥkām (ie: rulings) unless there is dalīl (ie: evidence) to suggest otherwise.
And I do not know of any sound evidence that distinguishes between men and women in this Sunnah.
quotes.title: Majmūʿ al-Fatāwá wa Rasāʿil

quotes.author: Muḥammad b. Ṣāliḥ al-ʿUthaymīn
quotes.body:
Q: “Where should a person praying place his two hands in prayer?
On his chest?
Or below his chest?
Or on his stomach?”
He may Allah have mercy on him answered:
The correct position is to place his two hands on the chest.
This is the best (and most correct opinion), and the evidence for this is the ḥadīth of Wāʿil b. Ḥajar, and this ḥadīth is Ḥasan.
quotes.title: Fatāwá Nūrun ʿalá ʾl-Darb

quotes.author: Muḥammad b. Ādam al-Ithīobī
quotes.body:
The author (ie: Muḥammad al-Ihtīobī) may Allah forgive him said: In light of al-adillah (Ie: the evidence), al-rājiḥ (ie: the most correct opinion) is that both hands should be placed on the chest during prayer.
Those who argue for tying the hands below the navel do not have any dalīl ṣaḥīḥ (to support them),
and those who argue for tying the hands above the navel do not have any evidence either, except that they may interpret placing the hands above the navel as meaning the chest.
And Allah the Exalted knows best what is correct.
quotes.title: Ḏakhīrah al-ʿUqbá fī Sharḥ al-Mujtabá

quotes.author: Muḥammad Nāṣir ʾl-Dīn al-Albānī
quotes.body:
(The Messenger ﷺ said): “Remember death in your prayer, for when a man remembers death in his prayer, it is likely that he will improve his prayer.
Pray the prayer of a man who does not think that he will pray any prayer other than it.
And beware of every matter from which one must apologize.”
Reported by al-Daylamī in Musnad al-Firdaws on the authority of Anas who raised it (to the Prophet ﷺ).
quotes.title: Silsilah al-Aḥādīth al-Ṣaḥīḥah

quotes.author: Ibn al-Qayyim
quotes.body:
You stand in your prayer with your body whilst you have turned your face towards al-qiblah (ie: direction of the Kaʿbah), but you have turned your qalb (ie: heart) towards another place?
What's the matter with you - this prayer is not suitable as mahr (ie: dowry) for al-Jannah (ie: Paradise),
so how could it be suitable as a price for al-maḥabbah (ie: love of Allah).
quotes.title: Badāʾi al-Fawāʾid

quotes.author: Muḥammad Nāṣir ʾl-Dīn al-Albānī
quotes.body:
[Ḥasan] On the authority of Abū Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet ﷺ he said:
“A man may pray for sixty years, and his prayer will not be accepted.
Perhaps he may complete al-rukūʿ (ie: the bowing) but not complete al-sujūd (ie: the prostration properly),
or he may complete al-sujūd but not complete al-rukūʿ (properly).”
quotes.title: Ṣaḥīḥ al-Tarġīb wa ʿl-Tarhīb
